comments.commentBody: Wrong.  They think they can get better profits from betting on the market they almost killed us with.

Nonsense. Economic collapse means that banks would not lend (and no one would want to borrow because they would not expect to be able to make a profit with the loaned money). It doesn't mean that an ATM would not dispense cash: The Federal Reserve would lend the money to the bank and the Treasury would print the currency.

Not good, but don't get overdramatic. In fact, the present economic stagnation with nearly 0% interest rates is pretty close to economic collapse---banks won't lend, and few businesses want to borrow anyway because they don't think they can make a profit even when the cost of borrowing is almost zero.
Mark:  What has Russia suggested and what are their long term national interests in this?

That's pretty slick spin you got there boy.
Muslims are killing Muslims and you found the reason.
It's all due to the Great Satan and the Zionists.

Muslims have fought Musilms for centuries. Each sect trying to impose their religous beliefs on the other. Each convinced the other was a heretic.

Columbus had yet to sail for the Indies, and these sectarian fault lines existed.

The Great Satan must move in mysterious ways.

"What we are doing now is just vicious. It is really effective only in clearing a way for Israel to attack Iran over Syria, when its air defenses fall into chaos. "

I don't follow you. What exactly, in your opinion, ARE we currently doing? Did you not read the entire article? We're not supporting the insurgents with anything other than Non-Lethal aid.

Our only effective option would be to use the Special Forces the way they were originally intended, the way they did things with the Northern Alliance in Afghanistan, and the Hmong in Vietnam. We would know who to trust if we ran them. We would know who had the missiles if we had them.

If we don't want to do that, we should not tear up the place with a civil war we fund and pump up. We could instead work with the Russians to get rid of Assad their way. They have offered a way.

What we are doing now is just vicious. It is really effective only in clearing a way for Israel to attack Iran over Syria, when its air defenses fall into chaos.
He had a lot of help from Teddy Kennedy in dealing with healthcare. A lot of help.

Was it just yesterday that the Times published an enlightening piece that put the lie to Willard's story about the bipartisanship he fostered during his single term as governor of Massachussetts?  It was a single term evidently because the good citizens of the Commonwealth had grown sick of him even despite the passage of universal health care.

Nomena,

Neither Brazil nor Italy have particularly outstanding women's coaches. Canada had an Italian coach right before John Herdman and they put in a disappointing performance at the 2011 WWC. I'm not sure why you singled out those 2 countries.

As for France, maybe they look prettier playing but USA beat them both at the WWC and at the Olympics. If USA hires away the Japanese coach, that would be very interesting. It would be unlikely though.

Hi.
For the next Wnt coach, i recommand an international coach.
Why not a brazilian or an Italian. The direct style of play was good for the past. A more tactical approach too will help team US making it better and more hard to beat. The last WC showed that France played a better football than team US and Japan could beat them with a style.

One last thing, if there is an area US player have to improve is technic. This sport is very entertaining if the games is played artisticly. Football is not only scoring, we want to see dribbling, technic, pass, pace... Those are part of the subtlety of the game true fans want to enjoy.
Thanks
You should look into other virtual pc software, such as VMware, that will allow you to run virtual XP wiithout Microsoft's Virtual Mode.

I don't know how you could have come up with your estimate of the top of screen height at below table height.  The cubes are 14 inches.  It's a much better scale than some unknown human.  That sets the legs at 4 inches and the screen at 24 inches.  Add in the 2 inch gap between screen and cube and you get 52 inches to the top of the screen.  That's a comfortable 22 inches above desk height.
Stupid error...baseball has...umpires not referees.

Paul, the dimensions of the cubes are provided: 14" (interior) and, from the website, 15.25" exterior. Add about 2.25" for the optional legs, and you have a little over 33" to the top of the second tier of cubes. Standard table height is a bit less than that.

All that aside, I do agree that much furniture photography would benefit from inclusion of readily recognizable human forms. Le Corbusier's Modular Man comes to mind.

I agree with your assessment of Ikea's flat-pack design philosophy. But it's hard to argue that a one-piece molding will be stronger than one that "snaps" together (seldom a long-term proposition). Besides, design maturity is not necessarily a leading characteristic for the folks at Quirky. Give them time - they may get there.

A couple of other ideas:
VMWare is one 3rd party software emulator. You can recreate the old machine with all installed software and files and make it reappear on the new computer in a window, although with a much faster processor. There are some quirks with peripherals to work through, but I've found this to be a good solution. You then get the benefit of new software operating in Windows 7 when you want it, or XP environment when needed.

Could a boot image of the original XP hard drive be made and installed on a new machine?

I believe the only iOS 6 device without a Youtube app at the moment would be the iPad although you can get a client app called Jasmine that does basically the same thing: http://itunes.apple.com/us/app/jasmine-youtube-client/id554937050?mt=8

I think it looks even better than the native iOS5 app and it works in the iPhone as well although the official iPhone app (by Google) should be more complete (especially now that it supports the 4" iP5 screen): http://itunes.apple.com/us/app/youtube/id544007664?mt=8

You can also purchase Windows 2008 R2 which comes pre-installed with Hyper-V-- Microsoft's virtualization software which is similar to VMWare.  You'll need a CPU which supports data execution protection (DEP).  Once you have Hyper-V you can spin up a virtual machine and install XP, or Linux if you wish..  Once you have your XP instance built you can connect to it via terminal services.  I might also note you can run Windows Server in a desktop mode which looks and feels identical to Windows 7.  I'm running this setup and it works great.
I'd love to see how any of these headphones would compare with Koss Portapros, which have been around for decades.
Try the Grado iGi. Also, there are music players themselves that don't start with "i" that are better at reproducing music, for example the Hifiman products.

I have to admit being fascinated by headphones and audio technology in general. For years I have been on something of a "holy grail" quest to find the perfect pair of earbuds or headphones. I have a pair of the Grado 60's which are great for listening at home, but I'm still trying to find a comfortable earbud that I can wear at the coffee shop while listening to my iPhone. Apple's new ear pods are an improvement but still tend to feel fatiguing after long periods. Thanks for the article!

Have had this phone (and the Flip cover) for about a month now w/o problems. I have a much more "protective" (and bulkier) cover for my year-old US Droid 3 and chose to go with the thinner, lighter option for the S III.

Fortunately I've never dropped either phone, but I can't imagine the Droid 3 escaping unscathed either.

I've been using this style of cover for my Galaxy Note for the past 10 months, and haven't missed the bulk of other covers.  This one has the added bonus of wiping my screen clean each time, which means my log-on pattern is no longer discernible to others.  With Gorilla glass, I don't worry so much about dropping it.  Although I haven't, I know others who have and the phone emerges unscathed by falls of about three feet.

When I first got notified that iGoogle was being killed, I searched around and ended up setting up a Protopage home page. It took about 2 days to essentially replicate my iGoogle page and I learned a bit more about RSS than I knew before, but it was not dificult (except to find the RSS feeds I wanted). Being free of iGoogle allowed me to  log OFF Google! I set my browser default home page to my custom Protopage. Works great and now it is harder for Google to track me (I do not use Gmail though have a Gmail account).

I used to have a metal case for an old Palm that was near-indestructible and not much thicker than this one.   It didn't replace the back; but used the stylus groove as an anchor point like a book binding, and had metal covers on back and front that clicked together to close.
What would be the more appropriate substitution of iGoogle for an iMac of all the options available?

These are glamorized milk crates with some wooden legs glued to the bottom.  I can't believe anyone would pay money for them.  Module-R is full of stuff like this that is cheap plastic for alot of money.  I don't know how they pay the rent because I don't see people buy much of their over priced stuff.

For a long time, there was competition among ISPs and other companies to convince users to set their browser "home page" to a "portal" allowing this customization - the feeling that this was a relatively easy way to sell advertising. It's interesting that this seems to have gone out of fashion.

Part of the reason might be that many browsers now start with a default that displays the most frequently visited pages (Chrome and Safari led with this functionality). Perhaps many also "graduated" from using their browser home page this way to using desktop-based applications, or decided that they would rather have more actual news presented to them. It's funny to me how many people I know that use nytimes.com as their home page.

I think the most likely explanation might be that people don't conceive of "going to the Internet" in some abstract sense, but launch browser sessions either from a link in an email, or with a definite destination in mind. My experience talking to people is that the novelty of having all sorts of interesting stuff greet you at the beginning of a session is outweighed (or negated) by wanting to get where you're going quickly and without an advertising-laden interim station.

(And, personally, I never really got iGoogle to do what I wanted - there seemed to be more of a learning curve with it than some other offerings; and I never actually go to Google's site to perform a search - another advantage of newer browsers).
who cares ?

Throeau101, it must have been some time since you've studied the Constitution. The Great Compromise resulted in each state getting two senators to give each an equal voice in one chamber of Congress. You want representation based on population?  That would be the House of Representatives where representation is based on population, and there, Wyoming only has 1 representative,  as compared to, say, the 53 reps California has. Rest assured, it all works the way the Framers intended, and it's proportionate.
ditto that- wherezit?

Someone please teach this fellow to write

"Offering two models, the $100 Laredo and the $226 Silverado, I preferred both sets to the rap star models I have listened to."

So the writer is offering two models? The dangling preposition ending the second sentence may be merely a style issue, but it is sloppy.
